resource.chars:
Now there is an ambiguity which must be noticed 
here at starting - as it is one which has caused 
much confusion and must, unless cleared up 
cause our conception of the real structure of the 
ascidian to be very indistinct - Authors 
speak of the greater or less adherence of the outer 
and inner <s>[text?]<\s> sacs - and consider the 
“outer sac” of the ordinary ascidian to be homologous 
with the outer tunic of the salpa - the 
“inner sac” again is with them homologous 
with the inner tunic of the salpa - But it is 
not so - Every ascidian as M. Milne Edwards has clearly 
shewn in Clavelina consists of three tunics - an outer 
- the <u>Test<\u> - a middle - which is here called outer <u>tunic <\u> and 
an inner - the inner <\u>tunic<\u> - The inner tunic of the 
salpa answers to the inner tunic of clavelina but 
its outer tunic answers to the test and the outer <u>tunic <\u> together
